title: Text
description: A *text* is the fundamental unit of documentation. It represents a linguistic performance of a stretch of discourse in context. This may include a wide variety of linguistic genres: an elicitation session, a conversation, a narrative, a song, etc. In technical terms, a text is an interlinearized set of utterances with one or more transcriptions, translations, and optionally Leipzig-style glosses.
$comment: This is a top-level database object

type.title: Type
type.description: The type of object. Must be set to `Text`.

id.title: ID
id.description: A unique database identifier for this Text

access.title: Access Rights
access.description: An object describing the acess rights to this Text

annotations.title: Annotations
annotations.description: A collection of annotations on this text

bibliography.title: Bibliography
bibliography.description: A list of citations to any bibliographic sources concerning or relating to this Text

items.title: Citation
items.description: A citation to a bibliographic source about this text

contributors.title: Contributors (People)
contributors.description: A collection of people who contributed to the creation or analysis of this text in some way. This should miniimally include the speaker(s) who produced the text.

items.title: Contributor (Person - DatabaseReference)
items.description: A database reference to a Person object that describes this contributor.

dateCreated.title: Date Created
dateCreated.description: The date and optionally time that this Text was created in the database (**not** the date it was recorded; see the `dateRecorded` property instead)

dateModified.title: Date Modified
dateModified.description: The date and optionally time that this Text object was last modified (**not** the date that the recording of the text was modified)

dateRecorded.title: Date Recorded
dateRecorded.description: The date and optionally time that this text was recorded

discourseType.title: Discourse Type
discourseType.description: The type, or types, of discourse event, e.g. monologue, dialogue, or song

genre.title: Genre
genre.description: The genre, or genres, of the text, e.g. folktale, personal narrative, or expository

languages.title: Languages
languages.description: A list of languages used in this text. If only one language is provided, all utterances in the text are assumed to be in that language, unless otherwise specified on specific utterances (using the `Utterance.language` property).

items.title: Language (DatabaseReference)
items.description: A database reference to a language that is used in this text. This property is most useful when working with lexical data from multiple languages.

link.title: Link
link.description: A URL where a presentational format for this resource may be viewed

location.title: Location
location.description: A database reference to the location where this text was recorded

media.title: Media
media.description: An array of objects containing information about the media files associated with this Text. Usually this will include the WAV or video file that was originally recorded for the text, but can also include any derivative media files (such as MP3) as well. Media associated with a text are automatically considered to be part of the same database bundle as the Text.

items.title: Media Items (Database Reference)
items.description: A database reference to an object describing a media file

notes.title: Notes
notes.description: A collection of notes about this Text

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: A set of tags associated with this Text

title.title: Title
title.description: A title is a human-readable prose description of the content of the Text. The `title` object contains all the titles of the text, in one or more languages (at least one must be provided). Each attribute in the `title` object should be the abbreviation of a language, and its value should be the title of the text in that language.

url.title: URL
url.description: The URL where this data can be retrieved in JSON format

utterances.title: Utterance
utterances.description: A collection of all the Utterances contained in this Text. The DLx specification imposes no requirements regarding how the linguist should segment the text into Utterances. The linguist may decide to segment their text based on intonation units, turns, or any other appropriate linguistic subdivision. The order of Utterances in the collection must reflect their actual order in the Text. Utterances do *not* have to be JSON unique - an Utterance may be repeated in a text. However, utterances are conceptually unique: each utterance represents a different token of speech.

access.notes: This text may be disseminated publicly, provided proper attribution is given to Chief Benjamin Paul and the Chitimacha Tribe.
